stream_context.summary: Entire session devoted to inventing a faux-bump-mapped “styrofoam” material for a new mountain stage; Kaze experiments with Blender, texture searches, AI prompts and N64-era shader tricks before settling on a plan to pre-compute multiple rotated normal maps and update them at runtime.

development_findings.summary: Game will ultimately contain 15 courses in total.
development_findings.quote: There’s going to be 15 courses in total.

development_findings.summary: Mountain stage might use a styrofoam-looking rock surface; goal is lower polygon count and a fresh material variety.
development_findings.quote: Making this mountain I had the idea that maybe making a styrofoam thing with better beach ... we could do this in less polygons and would be another interesting material to add.

development_findings.summary: Lilaa’s code idea was integrated, saving roughly 30 CPU instructions, though Kaze calls resulting math routine "cursed."
development_findings.quote: Your idea worked ... it saved like 30 instructions or so.

development_findings.summary: Kaze decides on a custom faux-bump approach: export a seamless normal map, generate 5-8 rotated versions, and each frame multiply vertex normals with light & camera vectors to derive per-pixel brightness stored in the texture palette.
development_findings.quote: We’ll pre-compute eight normal maps ... overwrite the normal maps every frame with the percentage of light it should reflect into the camera.

development_findings.summary: He dismisses using N64’s traditional lighting or high-overdraw hacks because they either sacrifice performance or can’t handle variable orientations.
development_findings.quote: Why don’t we just use lights? ... It only works on one normal so that doesn’t work.

development_findings.summary: Multiple tools tested (Blender displacement, Voronoi noise, AI image generation) but none produced a convincing seamless texture; ends stream after recruiting X-Linx to photograph real styrofoam.
development_findings.quote: At this point it would have been faster to 3D-model this texture. I did not think making styrofoam would turn into this much of a disaster.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is visibly frustrated by off-topic chat questions and social demands during development streams.
context_findings.quote: My least favorite thing about streaming is people asking me stuff that doesn’t relate to what I’m doing right now. I just want to work on my game.

context_findings.summary: He feels learning new tools (Blender materials, shader nodes) is draining but necessary.
context_findings.quote: Learning new tech is always so goddamn annoying.

key_stories.title: The Styrofoam Texture Saga
key_stories.summary: Kaze spends an entire session trying—and failing—to craft a believable styrofoam material for a mountain level. After exhausting online textures, AI tools, and Blender displacement tricks, he invents a plan to fake bump-mapping on N64 by swapping rotated normal maps each frame.
key_stories.challenge: Need a low-poly yet visually rich mountain surface material.
key_stories.process: Tried JPEG textures, sponge and cobblestone substitutes, Blender displacement, AI generation; consulted chat; reviewed N64 bump-mapping articles; designed custom normal-map swapping technique.
key_stories.outcome: No final texture yet, but clear technical roadmap and community member (X-Linx) tasked with photographing real styrofoam.
key_stories.key_quote: We’re going to export a normal map and overwrite it every frame with the percentage of light it should reflect—this will look really good.
